content: In short, the mammoths died out at a time when the island still had enough plants to feed them and space for them to live on, but when the quality and amount of water had precipitously declined. It’s because of this that the research team believes thirst ultimately killed the mammoth population. It’s also a reminder that climate change can damage ecosystems without inundating an area. Freshwater contaminated by saltwater seeping in from the ocean can kill plants and effectively poison animals, leading to dramatic ecological changes in a relatively short period of time.
